content: we would need to automatically add a to-announce to finished FCPs on rust repo
@simulacrum we've talked about this, but I don't remember the outcome but I guess this is not problematic, right?
I think last time I mentioned that really we should just de-tag things as FCP finished perhaps
but I don't have a strong opinion
Sorry for the possibly wrong comment, is that the same as this comment? i.e. rename a topic when priorit. has finished?
@apiraino nope, is not that
it is about github issues not zulip stuff

@Santiago Pastorino (or anyone who wants to jump in) Now the to-announce label is available, is the issue still valid as described on github?
Can you give me a bit more context on the tool that should do the job to auto-add this label? Is there something that reacts and apply labels? Or is it more on the github level (e.g. an action or something scripted there)?
I'd like to try helping on implementing this (provided it's not too much burden getting me the context to operate)
By the way, I wonder is this other issue https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues/2 has a similar content (autolabel an issue as a reaction to an event)

apiraino said:

Santiago Pastorino (or anyone who wants to jump in) Now the to-announce label is available, is the issue still valid as described on github?
Can you give me a bit more context on the tool that should do the job to auto-add this label? Is there something that reacts and apply labels? Or is it more on the github level (e.g. an action or something scripted there)?
I'd like to try helping on implementing this (provided it's not too much burden getting me the context to operate)

this is ready to be implemented, it's done in triagebot
check the code because we already handle to-announce for newly created MCPs on compiler-team repo
this needs to be done in rust repo for finished FCPs

apiraino said:

By the way, I wonder is this other issue https://github.com/rust-lang/compiler-team-prioritization/issues/2 has a similar content (autolabel an issue as a reaction to an event)

right, it's a similar idea :)
